sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of environmental event occurring in a region
message_1: A certain species of bird has a 30% chance of being found in a particular forest. If a researcher randomly selects 10 locations in the forest, what is the probability that the bird will be found in at least 3 of the locations?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of finding the bird in exactly k locations
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time (n! / (k!(n-k)!))
- p is the probability of finding the bird in a single location (30% or 0.3)
- n is the number of locations (10)
- k is the number of locations where the bird is found

We want to find the probability of finding the bird in at least 3 locations, so we need to calculate the probabilities for k = 3, 4, 5, ..., 10 and sum them up.

P(X >= 3) = P(X = 3) + P(X = 4) + ... + P(X = 10)

Calculating each probability:

P(X = 3) = C(10, 3) * 0.3^3 * 0.7^7 ≈ 0.2668
P(X = 4) = C(10, 4) * 0.3^4 * 0.7^6 ≈ 0.3504
P(X = 5) = C(10, 5) * 0.3^5 * 0.7^5 ≈ 0.1029
P(X = 6) = C(10, 6) * 0.3^6 * 0.7^4 ≈ 0.0368
P(X = 7) = C(10, 7) * 0.3^7 * 0.7^3 ≈ 0.0076
P(X = 8) = C(10, 8) * 0.3^8 * 0.7^2 ≈ 0.0009
P(X = 9) = C(10, 9) * 0.3^9 * 0.7^1 ≈ 0.0001
P(X = 10) = C(10, 10) * 0.3^10 * 0.7^0 ≈ 0.0000 (rounded)

Adding up the probabilities:

P(X >= 3) ≈ 0.2668 + 0.3504 + 0.1029 + 0.0368 + 0.0076 + 0.0009 + 0.0001 + 0.0000 ≈ 0.7655

So, the probability of finding the bird in at least 3 of the 10 locations is approximately 76.55%.
